items.content_html: Good night, Half Moon Bay.

items.title: Alexa, Scare Me To Death, Please!
items.content_html:
Buzzfeed is reporting that some users of Amazon‚Äôs Echo devices are feeling a bit creeped out at the fact that Alexa‚Äîa piece of software running on a cheap, crappy speaker‚Äîis ‚Äúlaughing‚Äù at them:

One person who was on the verge of falling into a peaceful slumber described hearing a ‚Äúvery loud and creepy laugh‚Äù from his Echo Dot. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a good chance I get murdered tonight,‚Äù he tweeted.

It‚Äôs amazing what people will willingly do to themselves, their families, and their own sanity simply because it‚Äôs somehow gotten too difficult to touch a phone.
Good morning, Half Moon Bay.
There should be a word for that moment when a tap target moves right before you tap it, leading you to tap something else. This new word should probably have more than 4 letters.
We need a Manhattan Project to build networking equipment that actually works at least 30% of the time. Dream big.

The next time you consider putting a caller on speakerphone while walking around in a public place, please reconsider.

‚Äî Decent Human Beings
Behind every frustrating session of debugging, there‚Äôs a really simple, stupid mistake.

Boo-hoo!

FBI security expert: Apple are ‚Äújerks‚Äù about unlocking encrypted phones
It‚Äôs Friday night, and I face a crucial decision: whisky, or whiskey?
Whenever my girlfriend and I are having trouble deciding what to eat for dinner, my ready suggestion is always Mexican food. It‚Äôs nice to have a default position when it comes to tricky problems.
A couple of scavenging ravens.
OK. Why?
Our little seaside town has a number of great restaurants, and on some occasions one or two of them are open for part of a half of a day.
All the hip developers are moving their server logic to the front end. But why? ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
A life so full of tragedy. It‚Äôs too much to bear.
I pulled some muscle or something in my chest, and to say the pain is horrible would be putting it mildly. It‚Äôs hard to do anything‚Äîeven nothing at all.
This is what you see now when you go to a Twitter URL while not logged in. Blatant lies, as per usual in our times.

items.title: NRA Gives Insane Award, Insanely
items.content_html:
The mind boggles at the thought that anyone could seriously believe that Ajit Pai ‚Äúsaved the Internet‚Äù and our ‚Äúfree speech rights‚Äù by overturning rules meant to protect the free flow of ideas from corporate intervention.

Hey, the world needs a few liars and lunatics, right?
Weird weather on the coast today.
Good for him.
This is a terrible dialog box (on Amazon.com). If I want to cancel, should I hit ‚Äúcancel?‚Äù Will that cancel my cancelation?

items.title: Login Forms Are Getting More User-Hostile
items.content_html:
There are (at least) two really annoying login approaches I‚Äôm seeing everywhere on the Web these days:

  1. Not putting a login form on the index page, opting for a signup form instead;
  2. Not displaying the password field until after a username has been entered.

The first one is largely due to lame ‚Äúgrowth-hacking.‚Äù The second is a lame response to the rise in malicious login attempts I noted in my post last night.

We cannot have nice things.
43% of all login attempts across the Web are malicious, Akamai claims. Authentication on the Web is a farcical mess.
Someday I hope to find a work space that is remotely workable. Some distant day.
UPS is really terrible at pretty much everything, making them the perfect company to represent this historical moment.
